Q1.ui:title: Describe the inputs, activities, and outputs that lead or could lead to these impacts
Q1.ui:tooltipshadding: Please specify the inputs, activities, and outputs that lead or could lead to actual and potential waste related impacts.Include: The types of inputs and outputs can include raw materials, process and manufacturing materials, leaks and losses, waste, by-products, products, or packaging.

Q2.ui:title: Describe whether these impacts relate to waste generated in the organization's own activities or to waste generated upstream or downstream in its value chain.
Q2.ui:tooltipshadding: Please provide the description of the impacts relate to waste generated in the organization's own activities or to waste generated upstream or downstream in its value chain. Impacts: effect the organization has or could have on the economy,environment, and people, including on their human rights, which in turn can indicate its contribution (negative or positive) to sustainable development.

fields.name: Waste - Management of significant waste - Management of significant waste

Q1.ui:title: Describe actions taken to prevent waste generated from organization's own activities, upstream activities and downstream activities in its value chain
Q1.ui:hadding: Actions taken to prevent waste generation and to manage significant impacts from waste generated
Q1.ui:tooltipstitle: Include: Actions mentioned should include actions including circularity measures.
Q1.ui:tooltipshadding: Include: Actions mentioned should include actions including circularity measures.

Q2.ui:title: If the waste generated by the organization in its own activities is managed by a third party, describe of the processes used to determine whether the third party manages the waste in line with contractual or legislative obligations.
Q2.ui:tooltipstitle: Third-party: Third party includes a public or private waste management organization, or any other entity or group of individuals formally or informally involved in handling the reporting organization's waste.Include: Agreements in a contract for the third party to follow when managing its waste, or rely on existing legislative obligations, such as local environmental laws and regulations
Q2.ui:tooltipshadding: This section documents the data corresponding to the waste generated by the organization in its own activities is managed by a third party.

Q3.ui:title: Describe the processes used to collect and monitor waste-related data
Q3.ui:tooltipstitle: Please specify the processes used to collect and monitor waste-related data. Include: Processes can include online data entry, maintaining a centralized database, real-time weighbridge measurement, and annual external data validation.
Q3.ui:tooltipshadding: This section documents the data corresponding to the processes used to collect and monitor waste-related data.

Unit.title: Unit
Unit.tooltiptext: Use 1000 kilograms as the measure for a metric ton.

WasteType.title: Waste Type
WasteType.tooltiptext: Please specify the type of waste. e.g. Paper waste, E-waste, chemical waste etc.

Wastecategory.title: Waste category
Wastecategory.tooltiptext: Select the waste category from the given dropdown.

Q1.ui:title: Provide contextual information necessary to understand the data and how the data has been compiled.
Q1.ui:tooltipstitle: Please provide contextual information necessary to understand the data and how the data has been compiled. e.g. any standards, methodologies etc. used for data compilation.
Q1.ui:tooltipshadding: Please provide contextual information necessary to understand the data and how the data has been compiled. e.g. any standards, methodologies etc. used for data compilation.

fields.name: Waste - Waste directed from disposal - Wasted diverted from disposal

Site.title: Site
Site.tooltiptext: On-site: 'Onsite' means within the physical boundary  or administrative control of the reporting organization Off-site: 'Offsite' means outside the physical boundary \ or administrative control of the reporting organization

Unit.title: Unit
Unit.tooltiptext: Use 1000 kilograms as the measure for a metric ton.

WasteType.title: Waste Type
WasteType.tooltiptext: Please specify the type of waste. e.g. Paper waste, E-waste, chemical waste etc.

Wastecategory.title: Waste category
Wastecategory.tooltiptext: Select the waste category from the given dropdown.

RecoveryOperations.title: Recovery Operations
RecoveryOperations.tooltiptext: Recovery: Operation wherein products, components of products,or materials that have become waste are prepared to fulfill a purpose in place of new products, components, or materials that would otherwise have been used for that purpose.Recovery Methods: Preparation for reuse: Checking, cleaning, or repairing operations, by which products or components of products that have become waste are prepared to be put to use for the same purpose for which they were conceived.Recycling: Reprocessing of products or components of products that have become waste, to make new materials

Unit.title: Unit

WasteType.title: Waste Type
WasteType.tooltiptext: Please specify the type of waste. e.g. Paper waste, E-waste, chemical waste etc.

Wastecategory.title: Waste category
Wastecategory.tooltiptext: Select the waste category from the given dropdown.

Methodofdisposal.title: Method of disposal
Methodofdisposal.tooltiptext: Disposal: Any operation which is not recovery, even where the operation has as a secondary consequence the recovery of energy Landfilling: Final depositing of solid waste at, below, or above ground level at engineered disposal sites Incineration: Controlled burning of waste at high temperatures

fields.name: Materials - Materials used by weight or volume - Non renewable

Unit.title: Unit
Unit.tooltiptext: Use 1000 kilograms as the measure for a metric ton.

Source.title: Source
Source.tooltiptext: Where does the company get its materials from? Internally sourced materials: Materials that the company makes itself.Externally sourced materials: Materials that the company buys from other companies.

Datasource.title: Data source
Datasource.tooltiptext: What is the source of the data for the total weight or volume of materials used? Estimation: process of making an approximate calculation of something.Direct measurement: process of measuring something directly. For example, a company might directly measure the total weight or volume of materials used by weighing or measuring each batch of materials used.

Totalweight.title: Total weight/volume
Totalweight.tooltiptext: How much material is used for the production of goods or services?(Please specify the total weight or volume.)

Materialsused.title: Materials used
Materialsused.tooltiptext: What materials does the compa use to produce its goods or services?

Typeofmaterial.tooltiptext: Select the waste category from the given dropdown.

fields.name: Water and effluents - Interaction with water - Interaction with water

Q1.ui:title: Describe how the organization interacts with water.
Q1.ui:hadding: Interactions with Water as shared resource
Q1.ui:tooltipstitle: In the description, include how, and where water is withdrawn, consumed, and discharged, as well as water-related impacts the organization has caused or contributed to, or those that are directly related to its operations, products, and services. An overview of water use across the organization s value chain.

Q2.ui:title: Describe the approach used to identify water-related impacts
Q2.ui:tooltipstitle: Include scope of assessments, their timeframe, and any tools or methodologies used.

Q3.ui:title: Describe how water-related impacts are addressed
Q3.ui:tooltipstitle: Include how the organization works with stakeholders to steward water as a shared resource, and how it engages with suppliers or customers with significant water-related impacts

Q4.ui:title: Describe the process for setting any water-related goals and targets that are part of the Organization's approach to managing water-related impacts.
Q4.ui:tooltipstitle: Include water-related goals and targets that are part of the organization s approach to managing water and effluents, and how they relate to public policy and the local context of each area with water stress

fields.name: Water and effluents - Interaction with water - Management of water discharge

Q1.ui:title: Describe any minimum standards set for the quality of effluent discharge.
Q1.ui:tooltipstitle: Include a description of standards used to set the quality of effluent discharge.

Q2.ui:title: Describe the process of determining discharge standards for facilities with no local discharge requirements
Q2.ui:tooltipstitle: ndicate how the company determine discharge standards for facilities without local discharge requirements.(Please specify the identification method use to determine standards (if any)

Q3.ui:title: Describe internally developed water quality standards or guidelines used (if any)
Q3.ui:tooltipstitle: Include how the organization works with stakeholders to steward water as a shared resource, and how it engages with suppliers or customers with significant water-related impactsDescribe how the internally developed water quality standards or guidelines were determined.

Q4.ui:title: Describe the sector-specific standards or guidelines used (if any)
Q4.ui:tooltipstitle: Provide a description of how the sector-specific standards were considered

fields.name: Water and effluents - Interaction with water - Profile of receiving waterbody

Q1.title: option

fields.name: Water and effluents - Water withdrawal/discharge from all areas - Water withdrawal/discharge from all areas

Unit.title: Unit
Unit.tooltiptext: Select the correct unit corresponding to the quantity of water withdrawal/discharge

Source.title: Source
Source.tooltiptext: Indicate where the company withdraws water from or Where the company discharges water into.Include (where applicable)the breakdown od water withdrawal and discharge data by: Surface Water; Ground water; Seawater; Produced water Third-party water

enum: Freshwater (Below or equal to 1000 mg/L Total Dissolved Solids)
other water (>1000 mg/L Total Dissolved Solids)
Watertype.title: Water type
Watertype.tooltiptext: Provide a breakdown of total water withdrawal/discharge from each of the sources by following categories of water: 1) Freshwater: water with concentration of total dissolved solids equal to or below 1,000 mg/L. 2) Other water: Other water constitutes any water that has a concentration of total dissolved solids higher than 1,000 mg/L.

discharge.title: Total water discharge
discharge.tooltiptext: Indicate the total amount of water discharged

withdrawal.title: Total water withdrawal
withdrawal.tooltiptext: Indicate the total amount of water withdrawn

Businessoperations.title: Business operations
Businessoperations.tooltiptext: Indicate the business operations for which water is withdrawn or discharged Include: Upstream operations - Upstream operations include identifying, extracting, or producing materials. For example, raw material extraction & transportation. Downstream operations - It refer to the final processes in the production and sale of goods, where finished products are created and sold to consumers. For example, logistic and packaging, distribution of product etc. Onsite water usage - For example, in service based companies water is used onsite for cleaning and maintenance, general sanitation etc.

fields.name: Water and effluents - Water withdrawal/discharge from all areas - Third party

Unit.title: Unit
Unit.tooltiptext: Select the correct unit corresponding to the quantity of water discharge.

Volume.title: Volume of water
Volume.tooltiptext: Indicate the amount of water sent for use to other organisation

Discharge.title: Do you discharge third-party water and send it to use for other organizations?
Discharge.tooltiptext: Third party water is defined as: municipal water suppliers and municipal wastewater treatment plants, public or private utilities, and other organizations involved in the provision, transport, treatment, disposal, or use of water and effluent if you discharge third-party water and it is sent to use for other organizations, then please provide the volume of the total water sent for use to other organizations

fields.name: Water and effluents - Water withdrawal/discharge from areas water stress - Water withdrawal/discharge from areas water stress

Unit.title: Total water storage at the beginning of the reporting period
Unit.tooltiptext: Select the correct unit corresponding to the quantity of water withdrawal/discharge.

Source.title: Source
Source.tooltiptext: Indicate where the company withdraws water from or Where the company discharges water into.Include (where applicable)the breakdown of water withdrawal and discharge data by: Surface Water; Ground water; Seawater; Produced water Third-party water

Pincode.title: Pin code
Pincode.tooltiptext: Mention the pin code of the area or location (of Water stress area) where the organization withdraws water from or discharges it into.

enum: reshwater (Below or equal to 1000 mg/L Total Dissolved Solids)
other water (>1000 mg/L Total Dissolved Solids)
Watertype.title: Water type
Watertype.tooltiptext: According to disclosure 303-3(c) of GRI company shall provide a breakdown of total water withdrawal from each of the sources by following categories of water: 1) Freshwater: water with concentration of total dissolved solids equal to or below 1,000 mg/L. 2) Other water: Other water constitutes any water that has a concentration of total dissolved solids higher than 1,000 mg/L.

waterstress.title: Name of water stress area
waterstress.tooltiptext: Which area or location does the organization withdraw water from or discharge it into?

Waterdischarge.title: Water discharge
Waterdischarge.tooltiptext: Indicate the total amount of water discharged by the company into the water stress area?

Waterwithdrawal.title: Water withdrawal
Waterwithdrawal.tooltiptext: Indicate the total amount of water withdrawn by the organization from the water stress area

Businessoperations.title: Business operations
Businessoperations.tooltiptext: Upstream operations: Upstream operations include identifying, extracting, or producing materials. For example, raw material extraction & transportation. Downstream operations: It refer to the final processes in the production and sale of goods, where finished products are created and sold to consumers. For example, logistic and packaging, distribution of product etc. Onsite water usage: For example, in service based companies water is used onsite for cleaning and maintenance, general sanitation etc.

Discharge.title: Do you withdraw water from third-parties?
Discharge.tooltiptext: Do you withdraw water from third parties? if yes then please provide a breakdown of the total third party-water withdrawn by the withdrawal sources. Third-party water: municipal water suppliers and municipal wastewater treatment plants, public or private utilities, and other organizations involved in the provision, transport, treatment, disposal, or use of water and effluent

fields.name: Water and effluents - Substances of concern - Substances of concern

Priority.tooltiptext: Indicate how does the company define the priority substances of concern

Discharge.title: Do you discharge any substances of concern
Discharge.tooltiptext: Do you withdraw water from third parties? if yes then please provide a breakdown of the total third party-water withdrawn by the withdrawal sources. Noncompliance.title: No of noncompliance incident
Noncompliance.tooltiptext: Indicate the number of times the organization has engaged in unauthorized discharges (non-compliance incidents) exceeding compliance limits? (if any)

Substanceconcern.title: Substance of concern
Substanceconcern.tooltiptext: Mention the substances of concern for which discharges are treated.In the context of GRI Standard, substances of concern are those that cause irreversible damage to the waterbody,ecosystem, or human health. For example: chemicals, pollutants, heavy metals, contaminants or any toxic substances.

fields.name: OHS - OHS management - OHS management system

Q1.ui:title: Has an Occupational Health & Safety Management System been implemented?
Q1.ui:tooltip: Please indicate whether you have a formal Occupational Health & Safety Management System implemented.

Q2.ui:title: Reason for implementation
Q2.ui:tooltip: Please explain the primary reason for implementing the system. For example: Compliance with legal requirements, adherence to industry standards, risk management and accident prevention, improvement of worker safety and well-being, enhancing corporate social responsibility, etc.

Q3.ui:title: List of legal requirements (if applicable)
Q3.ui:tooltip: List any specific legal regulations or laws that influenced the decision to implement the Occupational Health and Safety Management system. Include applicable national, regional, or industry-specific laws related to occupational health and safety.

Q4.ui:title: Standards/Guidelines
Q4.ui:tooltip: Indicate whether any recognized risk management or management system standards/guidelines were adopted in developing the system. Example: ISO 45001 (Occupational Health and Safety Management Systems)OHSAS 18001 (Occupational Health and Safety Assessment Series) National or industry-specific standards

Q5.ui:title: List of Standards/Guidelines (if applicable)
Q5.ui:tooltip: Provide a detailed list of the specific standards/guidelines that are used.Example: ISO 45001: Occupational Health and Safety Management Systems OHSAS 18001: Occupational Health and Safety Assessment Series Canada Labour Code: Part II - Occupational Health and Safety EU Directives on Occupational Safety and Health: Framework Directive (89/391/EEC) ASEAN-OSHNET Guidelines: Good Practices Guidance on various OSH topics

Q1.title: Has an Occupational Health & Safety Management System been implemented?

enum: Improvement of worker safety and well-being
Q2.title: Reason for implementation

fields.name: OHS - OHS management - Scope of workers

Q1.ui:title: Workers covered
Q1.ui:tooltip: Please mention the types of workers that are included in the scope of occupational health and safety management system. For example: Contractors, Temporary workers, Part-time employees, Interns, Volunteers, etc.

Q2.ui:title: Activities covered
Q2.ui:tooltip: Please mention the types of work activities that are covered in the scope of occupational health and safety management system. For example: Office work, Manual labor, Fieldwork, Manufacturing, Construction, Transportation, Research and development Maintenance, Customer service, Sales, etc.

Q3.ui:title: Workplaces Covered
Q3.ui:tooltip: Please mention the types of workplaces that are covered in the scope of occupational health and safety management system. For example: Office buildings, Manufacturing plants, Construction sites, Research facilities, etc.

Q4.ui:title: Exclusions (if any)
Q4.ui:tooltip: Please mention the locations or work environments where the scope of occupational health and safety management system does not apply. For example: Specific departments, Remote work locations, Client sites, Vehicles, Public spaces, etc.

Q5.ui:title: Reason for exclusion (if applicable)
Q5.ui:tooltip: Please provide the reason for exclusion, if applicable.

Q1.title: Workers covered

fields.name: OHS - Risk assessment - Process for hazard

Q1.ui:title: Routine Hazard Identification & Risk Assessment
Q1.ui:tooltip: Specify the exact timeframe or schedule for routine hazard identification.

Q2.ui:title: Non-Routine Hazard Identification & Risk Assessment
Q2.ui:tooltip: What events or circumstances prompt you to conduct hazard identification and risk assessment outside of routine schedules? (Select all that apply)

Q3.ui:title: Process for hazard identification
Q3.ui:tooltip: Select the methods used to identify work-related hazards on both a routine and non-routine basis. (Select all that apply)

Q4.ui:title: Hierarchy of controls
Q4.ui:tooltip: Select the methods used to identify. How do you prioritize and implement controls to address identified hazards? (Select all that apply)

Q5.ui:title: Legal or guideline basis
Q5.ui:tooltip: Are your hazard identification, risk assessment, and control processes based on any specific laws, regulations, or recognized standards/guidelines?

Q6.ui:title: List of legal requirements (if applicable)
Q6.ui:tooltip: List the specific laws or regulations your processes are based on, if applicable.

Q7.ui:title: Vulnerable Workers
Q7.ui:tooltip: List the specific regulations, or recognized standards/guidelines your processes are based on, if applicable.

Q1.title: Routine Hazard Identification & Risk Assessment

enum: Results of environmental or health surveillance
Q2.title: Non-Routine Hazard Identification & Risk Assessment

Q1.ui:title: Process Quality Assurance
Q1.ui:tooltip: Briefly mention key quality assurance practices (e.g., independent audits, feedback mechanisms, data analysis).

Q2.ui:title: Personnel Competency Assurance
Q2.ui:tooltip: Describe how you ensure personnel involved in hazard identification, risk assessment, and control implementation have the necessary skills and knowledge. This could include training programs, certifications, experience requirements, or internal competency assessments.

Q3.ui:title: Results Utilization and Improvement
Q3.ui:tooltip: Describe how you utilize findings from hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigations to continuously improve your occupational health and safety management system. (e.g., Analyze results, implement changes, track effectiveness, share lessons learned).

Q1.title: Process Quality Assurance

Q1.ui:title: Right to refuse unsafe work
Q1.ui:tooltip: Do workers have the right to refuse work they believe could cause injury or ill health?

Q2.ui:title: Policy and Process
Q2.ui:tooltip: Briefly describe the policy and process for workers to exercise their right to refuse unsafe work. For example: how workers notify supervisors, what triggers investigation, and how concerns are addressed.

Q3.ui:title: Protection from Reprisals
Q3.ui:tooltip: How are workers protected from reprisals for refusing unsafe work?

Q1.title: Right to refuse unsafe work

fields.name: OHS - Risk assessment - Work related incident

Q1.ui:title: Description of Incident
Q1.ui:tooltip: Please describe the processes used to investigate work-related incidents.Example: Incidents might be due to, for example, electrical problems, explosion, fire; overflow, overturning, leakage, flow; breakage, bursting, splitting; loss of control, slipping, stumbling and falling; body movement without stress; body movement under/with stress; shock, fright; workplace violence or harassment.

Q2.ui:title: Incident Reporting Personnel
Q2.ui:tooltip: Who can workers report work-related hazards and hazardous situations to? (Select all that apply)

Q3.ui:title: Investigation team
Q3.ui:tooltip: Who typically conducts incident investigations? (Select all that apply)

Q4.ui:title: Investigation Methods
Q4.ui:tooltip: What methods are used to investigate incidents? (Select all that apply)

Q5.ui:title: Hazard Identification & Risk Assessment
Q5.ui:tooltip: What actions did the organization take to address hazards and risks identified in incident investigations, following the hierarchy of controls? (Select all that apply)

Q6.ui:title: Corrective Actions
Q6.ui:tooltip: What actions did the organization take to address hazards and risks identified in incident investigations, following the hierarchy of controls? (Select all that apply)

Q7.ui:title: System Improvement
Q7.ui:tooltip: What changes did the organization make to policies, training, equipment, or communication after investigating incidents? (e.g., revised safety procedures, improved equipment, additional hazard training)

Q1.title: Description of Incident

Q1.ui:tooltip: Specify the occupational health services  functions that contribute to the identification and elimination of hazards and minimization of risks.

fields.name: OHS - OHS Services - Quality of services

Q1.ui:title: Does the organization ensure the quality of these services and facilitate workers access
Q1.ui:tooltip: Indicate whether the organization ensures the quality of the services and facilitates worker access.

Q2.ui:title: How the organization ensure the quality of these services and facilitate workers access
Q2.ui:tooltip: Describe how the organization ensures the quality of the services and facilitates worker access.Include:  1) How the organization maintains the confidentiality of workers  personal health related information. 2)How the organization ensures that workers  personal health-related information and their participation in any occupational health services is not used for any favorable or unfavorable treatment of workers

Q1.title: Does the organization ensure the quality of these services and facilitate workers access

Q2.title: How the organization ensure the quality of these services and facilitate workers access

Q1.ui:title: Is there a processes for worker participation and consultation in the development, implementation, and evaluation of the occupational health and safety management system?
Q1.ui:tooltip: Indicate whether the organization has any processes for worker participation and consultation in the development, implementation, and evaluation of the occupational health and safety management system

Q1.title: Is there a processes for worker participation and consultation in the development, implementation, and evaluation of the occupational health and safety management system?

Q1.ui:title: Describe the process and how access is provided to relevant information on occupational health and safety to workers
Q1.ui:tooltip: Provide a description of the process. The description can include the following information: formal participation, based on legal requirements   participation through engagement with formally recognized workers  representatives direct participation, particularly by affected workers (e.g., the direct involvement of all workers in occupational health and safety decisions in small organizations)   the use of committees, and how these committees are established and operated participation in the occupational health and safety management system (e.g., participation in identification of hazards, assessment of risks, application of the hierarchy of controls,investigation of incidents, audits, decision-making about the use of contractors and outsourcing)  how obstacles to participation are identified and removed (e.g., by providing training, by protecting workers against reprisals).

Q2.ui:title: How the process is communicated
Q2.ui:tooltip: Provide a description of the process. The description can include the following information: formal participation, based on legal requirements   participation through engagement with formally recognized workers  representatives direct participation, particularly by affected workers (e.g., the direct involvement of all workers in occupational health and safety decisions in small organizations)   the use of committees, and how these committees are established and operated participation in the occupational health and safety management system (e.g., participation in identification of hazards, assessment of risks, application of the hierarchy of controls,investigation of incidents, audits, decision-making about the use of contractors and outsourcing)  how obstacles to participation are identified and removed (e.g., by providing training, by protecting workers against reprisals).

Q1.title: Describe the process and how access is provided to relevant information on occupational health and safety to workers

titles.title: Number of fatalities as a result of work-related injury
titles.tooltip: Please specify the number of fatalities as a result of work-related injury. Work-related injury: negative impacts on health arising from exposure to hazards at work.

titles.title: Number of high-consequence work-related injuries (excluding fatalities)
titles.tooltip: Please specify the number of high-consequence work-related injuries (excluding fatalities).High-consequence work-related injury: work-related injury that results in a fatality or in an injury from  which the worker cannot, does not, or is not expected to recover fully to pre-injury health status within six months.

titles.title: Number of recordable work-related injuries
titles.tooltip: Please specify the number of recordable work-related injuries. Recordable work-related injury: work-related injury or ill health that results in any of the following: death, days away from work,restricted work or transfer to another job, medical treatment beyond first aid,or loss of consciousness

titles.title: Benefits
titles.tooltip: benefit definition: direct benefit provided in the form of financial contributions, care paid for by the organization, or the reimbursement of expenses borne by the employee. Example: Life Insurance, Health Care, Coverage, Parental Leave, Retirement Provision, Stock Ownership etc.

titles.title: Full-Time Employees
titles.tooltip: Please select if this benefit is standard for all full-time employees. Unselect if it's not offered.

titles.title: Part-Time Employees
titles.tooltip: Please select if this benefit is standard for all Part-time employees. Unselect if it's not offered.

titles.title: Temporary Employees
titles.tooltip: Please select if this benefit is standard for all Temporary employees. Unselect if it's not offered.

titles.title: Significant location of operations
titles.tooltip: This section allows you to enter the organization's significant locations of operation where the listed benefit is offered to full-time or part-time employees.

Q1.ui:title: How does the organization define Significant locations of operation for reporting purposes?
Q1.ui:tooltip: Please clarify how the organization defines and identifies its significant locations for reporting purposes.

Q1.title: How does the organization define Significant locations of operation for reporting purposes?

rowLabels.title: Parental Leave Entitlement
rowLabels.tooltip: This section refers to the total number of employees who meet the eligibility criteria for parental leave within the organization, regardless of whether they actually took leave.

rowLabels.title: Taking parental leave
rowLabels.tooltip: This section refers to the total number of employees who used their parental leave entitlement during the reporting period.

rowLabels.title: Returning to Work Post-Leave
rowLabels.tooltip: This section refers to the total number of employees who returned to work after their parental leave ended within the reporting period.

rowLabels.title: Retained 12 Months After Leave
rowLabels.tooltip: This section refers to the total number of employees who used their parental leave entitlement during the reporting period.
